frameDefinitions: A Figure is located relative to a Ground location.
Generally without overall (translational) motion,  an Agent places a Theme at a location, the Goal, which is profiled.
An Entity is judged to be sensually pleasing or intellectually interesting to a (generally implicit) Judge.
This frame contains perception words whose Perceivers have perceptual experiences that they do not necessarily intend to.
This frame contains perception words whose perceivers intentionally direct their attention to some entity or phenomenon in order to have a perceptual experience.
An Emitter emits a Beam of light from a Source, along a Path, and/or towards a Goal.
frameExamples: David <t>placed</t> his briefcase on the floor.
We saw this <t>beautiful</t> boat with the red sails several times
Abashed, realising that he had <t>overheard</t> her conversation with Victoria, Sheeley didn't try to make excuses.
Avoid allowing light to <t>shine</t> into neighbors' gardens.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Ground</fen> serves as a basis for describing the location of the <fen>Figure</fen>.
The <fen>Figure</fen> is perceived as located relative to a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location. The figure can be an entity or an event.
The <fen>Figures</fen> are items which mutually serve to identify the location of the other items.
The region within which a <fen>Figure</fen> might be found.  This role is exclusive of <fen>Figure</fen>, and is a reconstrual that is not possible with verb lexical units.
The period of time during which the locative relation between <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen> obtains.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person (or other force) that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to move.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the object that changes location during the Placing.
The role <fen>Goal</fen> is the location where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up. This role is profiled by words in this frame.
<fen>Time</fen> is when the Placing occurs
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates where the Placing occurs.
The <fen>Entity</fen> for which a particular gradable <fen>Attribute</fen> is appropriate and under consideration.
The feature of an <fen>Entity</fen> which is under discussion.
A modifier expressing    the deviation of the implicit value either from the norm or from the value for another <fen>Entity</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Entity</fen> is in the state of having a particular implicit value for the <fen>Attribute</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Entity</fen> is in the state of having a particular implicit value for the <fen>Attribute</fen>.
This role is the being who has a perceptual experience, not necessarily on purpose. It is typically expressed as an External Argument.
This role is the entity or phenomenon that the perceiver experiences with his or her senses. It is typically expressed as Object with verbs.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the location on the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>'s body where the perceptual experience  takes place.  It is typically expressed in a PP.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> or the <fen>Body_part</fen> perceives the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.
The <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> performs some action in order to have a perceptual experience. It is expressed as an External Argument:

<fen>Phenomenon</fen> indicates the entity or phenomenon to which the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> directs his or her attention in order to have a perceptual experience. Typically, it is expressed as an Object with verbs.
<fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the part of the body used as a sensory organ of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen>, typically expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.

<fen>Direction</fen> is used for all path-like expressions that describe how the perceiver's attention is directed during the act of perception, with the exception of those indicating the location of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> (which would be marked <fen>Location_of_perceiver</fen>)
When the activity of attempting to perceive occurs.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.
This role identifies the entity at the <fen>Source</fen> from which the <fen>Beam</fen> originates.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the location the <fen>Beam</fen> occupies initially before its change of location.
The light that travels from a <fen>Source</fen> along a <fen>Path</fen> to a <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Path</fen> refers to where the <fen>Beam</fen> travels over or to a landmark the <fen>Beam</fen> travels by.
<fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Beam</fen> ends up in.
listRoleExamples: <fex><t>Next to</t> the kitchen</fex> is the best place to locate your garage .
<fex>The waiter</fex> placed the food on the table.
The waiter placed <fex>the food</fex> on the table.
The waiter placed the food <fex>on the table</fex>.
Grass , which is sown with clover , provides rich pasture for cattle in summer and the clover is <fex>another plant which</fex> puts nitrogen into the soil .
Smithers had placed the table there <fex>the night before</fex>.
<fex>The waiter</fex> smelled something foul in the kitchen.
The waiter smelled <fex>something foul</fex> in the kitchen.
Marlow felt something cold and hard <fex>against the back of his neck</fex>.
<fex>The waiter</fex> smelled the milk to see if it was fresh.
The waiter smelled <fex>the milk</fex> to see if it was fresh.
You should feel the water <fex>with your toes</fex> before jumping in.
The detective looked <fex>across the street</fex> at the suspect.
<fex>Sunlight</fex> gleamed from the water of the bay.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Kona Manta Ray Night Dive
the Kona Manta Ray Night Dive
The Ocean Recreation Council of Hawaii
the Kona Manta Ray Night Dive
